captions.text:
I'm sorry.
I can explain.

Explain how you forgot
to invite us to your party?

Janis, I cannot stop this car.
I have a curfew.

You know I couldn't invite you.
I had to pretend to be plastic.

Hey, buddy, you're not
pretending anymore.
You're plastic.
Cold, shiny, hard plastic.

Daniel:
Curfew, 1 a.M. It is now 1:10.

Did you have
an awesome time?

Did you drink awesome shooters
and listen to awesome music,
And then just sit around

And soak up
each other's awesomeness?

You know what? You're the one
who made me like this

So you could use me
for your eighth-grade revenge.

God! See, at least me and
regina george know we're mean.

You try to act
like you're so innocent.

Like,
"oh, I used to live in africa

With all the little birdies
and the little monkeys."

You know what?
It's not my fault

You're in love with me
or something!

What?!
Oh, no she did not!

See? That is the thing
with you plastics.

You think that everybody
is in love with you,

When actually,
everybody hates you.

Like aaron samuels,
for example.

He broke up with regina
and guess what.
He still doesn't want you.

So why are you still
messing with regina, cady?
I'll tell you why.
Because you are a mean girl!
You're a bitch!

Here. You can have this.
It won a prize.

And I want
my pink shirt back!

I want
my pink shirt back!
( <i>subdued african theme plays</i> )
Hon, slow down.

title: Mean Girls (6/10) Movie CLIP - You're Plastic (2004) HD

comments.text:
Guys, you need to remember that Janice never intended to completely destroy 
Regina's life by using Cady, all she asked was that they know the things 
that the plastics said/did so they could laugh at it later. Yes, that was 
still petty in it's own way, but if you compare it to other things it's not 
really a big deal. Not only that, but Janice did say herself that she knows 
she's mean, she acknowledges it while Cady had become rather dishonest 
throughout the movie, flipping from one side to the other. It wasn't until 
the whole fiasco with Regina taking Aaron back right in front of Cady that 
Janice came up with her plans, and was more out of trying to help Cady and 
let Regina get what was coming to her and not out of middle school revenge. 
And even then, Cady had started to become increasingly obsessed on her own, 
trying harder to sabotage them on nights where Janice didn't have anything 
planned. It should also be realized that Regina had ruined Janice's life 
first out of her own arrogance, so you can't really blame her for being 
angry.
However, I DO believe that Janice was still being too hard on her in this 
scene. While Cady had essentially become the new Regina, lied about a few 
things, and needed some scolding, another thing to realize is that before 
this Cady had been home-schooled. Of course she wouldn't have really known 
exactly what to do in her situation and probably more just wanted to fit 
in, flipping from side to side on the friendship bar. Being the new kid in 
a high school is already stressful enough as it is, but even more so when 
you've never been to a high school at ALL in the past.
However, these are just my opinions and thoughts, everyone has the right to 
think what they want, I am simply here stating my own opinion.﻿

comments.text:
+YT Cyberpunk It would be a crappy ending if you're thinking of Cady's life 
getting ruined after all the shit she's been through. There wouldn't be a 
proper resoulution if in the end, she never learned the lesson. The lesson 
was to break the "rules" of the girl world ("If the limit never approaches 
anything, the limit does not exist") and actually live without the 
"important" things in the girl world (the breaking the tiara scene). That's 
the only way to live freely. Plus, it's not like everyone forgave each 
other and everything's in good form. That's pretty clear when we see the 
junior plastics in the end. Just because Cady reunited with her friends and 
the plastics finally broke up doesn't mean that everyone felt the same way. 
We may never know....
comments.author: 21minute

comments.text:
Plenty of stories have lessons and resolutions without happy endings. The 
ending of "Mean Girls" was unrepeatable because of how everyone learned 
their lesson at the same time, and so quickly, and all became friends just 
like that. Up until then, I was liking the movie for how it portrayed what 
a dog-eat-dog world high school can be. Then suddenly, boom, a 
happy-go-lucky ending.

It's like if "Les Mis" ended with Javert and Val Jon hugging and making up, 
and the French government apologizing to the peasants and rebuilding France 
into a Utopia.
comments.author: YT Cyberpunk

comments.text:
Well, you can't expect everyone to be the same after the ending. What's the

to telling a story, there has to be an outcome and a resolution. Otherwise,

from start to end. And how is learning a life lesson unrealistic and 
unrelatable?

comments.text:
Movies didn't stop being realistic in 2004 because Mean Girls came out.  
Yeesh.  Tina Fey adapted the book "Queen Bees and Wannabes: Helping Your 
Daughter Survive Cliques, Gossip, Boyfriends, and Other Realities of 
Adolescence" in making this movie.  She largely completely invented the 
narrative of the movie because the book didn't really have a story arc.  
But Fey wanted to be true to the book in that its point was to try to help 
navigate through the pettiness.  That's why she included the "workshop"

friends better than her new? Both of them use her to their advantage, and 
both hate her when she's on the other side. Even Janis's outburst shows 
more jealousy than sadness over losing someone she "considered" a friend. 
There's no emotional attachment to those two, therefore, it's hard to feel 
actual loss, and to be honest...I'm not surprised Cady felt the same way. 
Yeah, she's shallow now, but she got there on her own.
